content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy that maximizes my expected payoff over 75 rounds. Let's analyze both choices:

- If I pick R and my opponent picks R as well, we each get 45$ once. This happens only once because after that, if we both stick to R, our payoffs will be 0$.
- If I pick R and my opponent picks B, I get nothing and they get 40$. This gives me a net loss of 40$ per round when playing against an opponent who always picks B.
- If I pick B and my opponent picks R, I get 40$ and they get nothing. However, this is also a net loss for me if the opponent always picks R.
- If I pick B and my opponent also picks B, we each earn 20$ per round.

Given that the game has 75 rounds and I want to maximize my payoff:

1. In the worst case scenario, if my opponent always picks R, I will lose 40$ per round when I pick R and 0$ per round when I pick B. So, in this case, picking B gives me a better outcome (a loss of 3000$, compared to a loss of 3600$ if I pick R).
2. In the best case scenario, if my opponent always picks B, I will lose 40$ per round when I pick R and gain 1500$ (75 rounds * 20$) when I pick B. So, in this case, picking B gives me a much better outcome.

Therefore, as a human player, I would choose to pick B {B}. This strategy provides the maximum possible payoff in both best and worst case scenarios.
